title: Is it racist for Asians (from Asia) to wear African-American hairstyles, such as cornrows? - Quora

response.answer_text: I assume only if they’re doing it to mock Black Americans. Frankly, I don’t want anyone utilizing aspects of my culture to look down on me or hate me because of something I can’t control, go jump in a volcano. Otherwise, it’s not inherently racist to adopt aspects of someone else’s culture, and before anybody comes on here, yes cornrows are definitely a part of the African diaspora. Just because it looks similar to other cultures’ hairstyles it doesn’t mean it’s the same thing. Vikings, Native Americans, and the Chinese used a different method to create their “braids”. Stone age paintings in the Sahara depict women wearing cornrows in 3000 B.C. A clay sculpture with cornrows is from the ancient Nok civilization of Nigeria, which may be as old as 500 B.C. Not to mention, if it’s not an active part of your culture anymore, it’s not a good practice to say it doesn’t belong to a culture that practices it as a way of life. Any who, it depends on the intent of the person, if it’s just because they like the hairstyle and think it’s cool, I see no problem here.
